**John Dezso Ratzenberger** (born April 6, 1947)[1] is an American actor,
voice actor, and entrepreneur. He is best known as [Cliff
Clavin](/wiki/Cliff_Clavin "Cliff Clavin") in _[Cheers](/wiki/Cheers
"Cheers")_. He is also known for his extensive vocal work in [Pixar Animation
Studios](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar")' films, notably Hamm in the [_Toy Story_
franchise](/wiki/Toy_Story_\(franchise\) "Toy Story \(franchise\)") and Mack
in the [_Cars_ franchise](/wiki/Cars_\(franchise\) "Cars \(franchise\)").

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Ratzenberger was born in [Bridgeport,
Connecticut](/wiki/Bridgeport,_Connecticut "Bridgeport, Connecticut"), the son
of Bertha Veronica (née Grochowski), who worked for [Remington
Arms](/wiki/Remington_Arms "Remington Arms"), and Dezso Alexander
Ratzenberger, a [Texaco](/wiki/Texaco "Texaco") truck driver.[2][3] His father
was of Austrian and [Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarian_American "Hungarian American")
descent, and his mother was of [Polish](/wiki/Polish_American "Polish
American") ancestry.[4] He attended St. Ann's School in Bridgeport and [Sacred
Heart University](/wiki/Sacred_Heart_University "Sacred Heart University") in
Fairfield, Connecticut.[1] In 1969, Ratzenberger was a tractor operator at the
[Woodstock Festival](/wiki/Woodstock_Festival "Woodstock Festival").[5] He
moved to London in 1971 and stayed there for 10 years.[1]

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career")]

Ratzenberger was a house [framer](/wiki/Framer "Framer")[6] living in London
when he began his career in the performing arts.[1] Through the 1970s, he
performed with Ray Hassett as the comedic theatrical duo Sal’s Meat Market,
which toured across the UK.[7] Peter Richardson and [Nigel
Planer](/wiki/Nigel_Planer "Nigel Planer") as The Outer Limits and in The
Comic Strip were heavily influenced by Sal’s Meat Market.[8] His first role
was a patron in _[The Ritz](/wiki/The_Ritz_\(film\) "The Ritz \(film\)")_
(1976). Throughout the late 1970s and early 1980s, Ratzenberger appeared in
various minor roles in major feature films, including
_[Firefox](/wiki/Firefox_\(film\) "Firefox \(film\)")_ ; _[A Bridge Too
Far](/wiki/A_Bridge_Too_Far_\(1977_film\) "A Bridge Too Far \(1977 film\)")_ ,
as Lieutenant [James Megellas](/wiki/James_Megellas "James Megellas");
_[Superman](/wiki/Superman_\(1978_film\) "Superman \(1978 film\)")_ , as a
missile controller; _[Superman II](/wiki/Superman_II "Superman II")_ , as the
[NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA") control man; _[Star Wars: The Empire Strikes
Back](/wiki/The_Empire_Strikes_Back "The Empire Strikes Back")_ as Major [Bren
Derlin](/wiki/List_of_Star_Wars_characters#D "List of Star Wars characters");
_[Motel Hell](/wiki/Motel_Hell "Motel Hell")_ as a drummer;
[_Outland_](/wiki/Outland_\(film\) "Outland \(film\)") as a doomed mine worker
named Tarlow; and _[Gandhi](/wiki/Gandhi_\(film\) "Gandhi \(film\)")_ ,
playing an American lieutenant.

###
_Cheers_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Cheers")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/John_Ratzenberger_on_the_red_carpet_at_the_1992_Emmy_Awards.jpg/220px-
John_Ratzenberger_on_the_red_carpet_at_the_1992_Emmy_Awards.jpg)](/wiki/File:John_Ratzenberger_on_the_red_carpet_at_the_1992_Emmy_Awards.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:John_Ratzenberger_on_the_red_carpet_at_the_1992_Emmy_Awards.jpg
"Enlarge")

Ratzenberger at the [1992 Primetime Emmy
Awards](/wiki/44th_Primetime_Emmy_Awards "44th Primetime Emmy Awards")

Ratzenberger is well known for playing mail carrier [Cliff
Clavin](/wiki/Cliff_Clavin "Cliff Clavin") on the sitcom
_[Cheers](/wiki/Cheers "Cheers")_. He had read for the part of [Norm
Peterson](/wiki/Norm_Peterson "Norm Peterson"), but after the audition, he
sensed that they were not going to give him the part. Sensing an opportunity,
he asked if they had written a bar know-it-all, which the producers decided
was a great idea.[9] Ratzenberger also came up with the idea for Cliff's
trademark white socks, which he wore as a tribute to French comedian [Jacques
Tati](/wiki/Jacques_Tati "Jacques Tati").[10] Cliff became known for his
outlandish stories of plausible half-truths, uninteresting trivia, and
misinformation, and in general for being a pretentious blowhard. Cliff and
Norm, the primary customer characters, became iconic bar buddies. Ratzenberger
provided the voice for an animated version of Cliff on [_The Simpsons_ sixth-
season](/wiki/The_Simpsons_\(season_6\) "The Simpsons \(season 6\)") episode
"[Fear of Flying](/wiki/Fear_of_Flying_\(The_Simpsons\) "Fear of Flying \(The
Simpsons\)")".

When [Paramount Television](/wiki/Paramount_Television "Paramount Television")
licensed the look of the Cheers bar to the Host International subsidiary of
[Host Marriott Services](/wiki/Host_Marriott_Services "Host Marriott
Services") for use in airports in the U.S. and New Zealand, the group also
created [animatronic](/wiki/Animatronic "Animatronic") barflies. They were
called "Hank" and "Bob"; Ratzenberger and [George Wendt](/wiki/George_Wendt
"George Wendt") claimed Hank and Bob resembled them, and in January 1993, sued
Host for using their likenesses without permission.[11] The case languished in
court for eight years before all sides settled in 2001.[12]

###
Pixar[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Pixar")]

Ratzenberger has had a voice part in all of [Pixar's feature
films](/wiki/List_of_Pixar_films "List of Pixar films") made to date, ranging
from main characters to characters who appear in only one scene.[13] His roles
include:

  * [Hamm the Piggy Bank](/wiki/Hamm_the_toy "Hamm the toy") in the [_Toy Story_ series](/wiki/Toy_Story_\(franchise\) "Toy Story \(franchise\)") ([1995](/wiki/Toy_Story "Toy Story"), [1999](/wiki/Toy_Story_2 "Toy Story 2"), [2010](/wiki/Toy_Story_3 "Toy Story 3"), 2019)
  * P.T. Flea, the Circus Ring Leader in _[A Bug's Life](/wiki/A_Bug%27s_Life "A Bug's Life")_ (1998)
  * [The Abominable Snowman](/wiki/Yeti "Yeti") in the [_Monsters, Inc._ series](/wiki/Monsters,_Inc._\(franchise\) "Monsters, Inc. \(franchise\)") ([2001](/wiki/Monsters,_Inc. "Monsters, Inc."), [2013](/wiki/Monsters_University "Monsters University"))
  * The school of [Moonfish](/wiki/Silver_moony "Silver moony") in _[Finding Nemo](/wiki/Finding_Nemo "Finding Nemo")_ (2003)
  * [The Underminer](/wiki/The_Underminer "The Underminer") in _[The Incredibles](/wiki/The_Incredibles "The Incredibles")_ (2004)
  * [Mack the truck](/wiki/Mack_\(Cars\) "Mack \(Cars\)") in the [_Cars_ series](/wiki/Cars_\(franchise\) "Cars \(franchise\)") ([2006](/wiki/Cars_\(film\) "Cars \(film\)"), [2011](/wiki/Cars_2 "Cars 2"), [2017](/wiki/Cars_3 "Cars 3"))
  * Mustafa the waiter in _[Ratatouille](/wiki/Ratatouille_\(film\) "Ratatouille \(film\)")_ (2007)
  * John in _[WALL-E](/wiki/WALL-E "WALL-E")_ (2008)
  * Tom the construction worker in _[Up](/wiki/Up_\(2009_film\) "Up \(2009 film\)")_ (2009)
  * Gordon the guard in _[Brave](/wiki/Brave_\(2012_film\) "Brave \(2012 film\)")_ (2012)
  * Fritz in _[Inside Out](/wiki/Inside_Out_\(2015_film\) "Inside Out \(2015 film\)")_ (2015)
  * Earl the velociraptor in _[The Good Dinosaur](/wiki/The_Good_Dinosaur "The Good Dinosaur")_ (2015)
  * Bill the crab in _[Finding Dory](/wiki/Finding_Dory "Finding Dory")_ (2016)

Ratzenberger's tenure at Pixar was parodied during the end credits of
_[Cars](/wiki/Cars_\(film\) "Cars \(film\)")_ , where his character, Mack,
watches car-themed versions of Pixar films (_[Toy Car Story](/wiki/Toy_Story
"Toy Story")_ , _[Monster Trucks, Inc.](/wiki/Monsters,_Inc. "Monsters,
Inc.")_ , and _A[Bug](/wiki/Volkswagen_Beetle "Volkswagen Beetle")'s Life_).
Mack notes that all the characters Ratzenberger has played were excellent
until he realizes that they are performed by the same actor, at which point he
remarks, "They're just using the same actor over and over," and asks "What
kind of cut-rate production is this?!"

His favorite of his Pixar characters was P.T. Flea, because "in real life, I
always get a kick out of those kinds of characters, people who just go into a
rage for [no] explicable reason. He was always on edge. His blood pressure was
always way over the top, and everything that he did was done in a panicked
state. So it was a lot of fun to play him."[6] Although technically not Pixar
films, Ratzenberger also voiced Harland the jet tug in [DisneyToon
Studios](/wiki/DisneyToon_Studios "DisneyToon Studios")'
_[Planes](/wiki/Planes_\(film\) "Planes \(film\)")_ (2013)[14][15] and a
mustached plane named Brodi in its sequel, _[Planes: Fire&
Rescue](/wiki/Planes:_Fire_%26_Rescue "Planes: Fire & Rescue")_ (2014).[16]

### Reality show
appearances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Reality show appearances")]

During season six of _[Last Comic Standing](/wiki/Last_Comic_Standing "Last
Comic Standing")_ , Ratzenberger was a talent scout with his former _Cheers_
co-star George Wendt.

On March 2, 2007, he replaced [Vincent Pastore](/wiki/Vincent_Pastore "Vincent
Pastore") (who had quit after one week of training) on the [fourth season of
the American version](/wiki/Dancing_with_the_Stars_\(US_season_4\) "Dancing
with the Stars \(US season 4\)") of _[Dancing with the
Stars](/wiki/Dancing_with_the_Stars_\(US_TV_series\) "Dancing with the Stars
\(US TV series\)")_.[17] He was partnered with professional ballroom dancer
[Edyta Sliwinska](/wiki/Edyta_Sliwinska "Edyta Sliwinska"), who had been
Pastore's partner; the two were the sixth couple to be eliminated from the
show.

On December 3, 2009, Ratzenberger appeared on an episode of _[American
Chopper](/wiki/American_Chopper "American Chopper")_ to help promote awareness
of the Iraq Star Foundation.

On June 26, 2011, Ratzenberger was asked by NASCAR to give the shouting
command for the [2011 Toyota Save-Mart 350](/wiki/2011_Toyota/Save_Mart_350
"2011 Toyota/Save Mart 350") at [Sonoma](/wiki/Sonoma_Raceway "Sonoma
Raceway"). Ratzenberger accepted and gave the "Gentlemen, start your engines"
command.

On April 23, 2015, Ratzenberger appeared as a guest judge on the [14th
season](/wiki/Hell%27s_Kitchen_\(U.S._season_14\) "Hell's Kitchen \(U.S.
season 14\)") of _[Hell's Kitchen](/wiki/Hell%27s_Kitchen_\(U.S._TV_series\)
"Hell's Kitchen \(U.S. TV series\)")_ for an alcohol challenge, in nod to his
appearances on _[Cheers](/wiki/Cheers "Cheers")_.

### Additional voice, TV, and film
work[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Additional voice, TV, and film work")]

  * Guest starred as " Walter Brewster "in an episode of Magnum PI in 1984
  * Appeared in the sitcom _[Sabrina the Teenage Witch](/wiki/Sabrina,_the_Teenage_Witch_\(TV_series\) "Sabrina, the Teenage Witch \(TV series\)")_ as _Bob_ or Santa Claus (1997)
  * Hosted the [Travel Channel](/wiki/Travel_Channel "Travel Channel") TV series _[John Ratzenberger's Made in America](/wiki/John_Ratzenberger%27s_Made_in_America "John Ratzenberger's Made in America")_, about things made in the USA (2003–2008[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit))
  * Guest-starred in four episodes of the first season of [John Ritter](/wiki/John_Ritter "John Ritter")'s sitcom _[8 Simple Rules](/wiki/8_Simple_Rules "8 Simple Rules")_ as Paul Hennessy's overly friendly neighbor Fred Doyle
  * Hosts the Wildcard section in the PC version of the board game, _[Trivial Pursuit](/wiki/Trivial_Pursuit "Trivial Pursuit")_
  * Also appeared on _[That'70s Show](/wiki/That_%2770s_Show "That '70s Show")_ as Glen, a man stuck in an awful marriage with his high-school sweetheart whose negative example gives Eric second thoughts about marrying Donna
  * Played Thomas Foy in the TV movie _The Pennsylvania Miners ' Story_
  * As Shelly Cole star in _[The Village Barbershop](/wiki/The_Village_Barbershop "The Village Barbershop")_ (2008), written and directed by Chris Ford[18]
  * Made an appearance in _[Bill Nye the Science Guy](/wiki/Bill_Nye_the_Science_Guy "Bill Nye the Science Guy")_
  * Provided the voice of Rigger in the animated series _[Captain Planet and the Planeteers](/wiki/Captain_Planet_and_the_Planeteers "Captain Planet and the Planeteers")_
  * Made an appearance on British show _[Live from Studio Five](/wiki/Live_from_Studio_Five "Live from Studio Five")_ (February 17, 2010).
  * Appeared in television commercials for the [Pitney Bowes](/wiki/Pitney_Bowes "Pitney Bowes") personal post office, ended every commercial saying "Hey, I look good in red!"
  * Appeared in commercials for [Quality Hotels](/wiki/Choice_Hotels#Brands "Choice Hotels") and [Zaxby's](/wiki/Zaxby%27s "Zaxby's") restaurant chain (2010)
  * Plays Mike the Angel in _[What If...](/wiki/What_If..._\(2010_film\) "What If... \(2010 film\)")_ , a [Pure Flix Entertainment](/wiki/Pure_Flix_Entertainment "Pure Flix Entertainment")/Jenkins Entertainment movie release in 2010, also starring Kevin Sorbo, Kristy Swanson, and Debby Ryan[19]
  * Reprised his role of Cliff Clavin in an episode of _[Frasier](/wiki/Frasier "Frasier")_[20] and - along with his Cheers partner, George Wendt - an episode of _[Wings](/wiki/Wings_\(1990_TV_series\) "Wings \(1990 TV series\)")_ called "[The Story of Joe](/wiki/List_of_Wings_episodes "List of Wings episodes")"
  * Hosted the documentary, _Industrial Tsunami_ , intended to wake Americans up to the shortage of skilled workers threatening the existence of American companies and entire industries
  * Appeared in the final episode of _[Secret Army](/wiki/Secret_Army_\(TV_series\) "Secret Army \(TV series\)")_ entitled "The Execution" as a Canadian officer who is bribed by Standartenfuhrer Kessler's mistress Madeleine Duclos to spring Kessler from the POW camp where he is incarcerated
  * Starred in "A House Divided," the 28th episode of the first season of _[Melissa& Joey](/wiki/Melissa_%26_Joey "Melissa & Joey")_ as Arnie the neighbor
  * Voiced the bathhouse's assistant manager, Aniyaku, in the English [dub](/wiki/Dubbing_\(filmmaking\) "Dubbing \(filmmaking\)") of _[Spirited Away](/wiki/Spirited_Away "Spirited Away")_
  * Made a cameo in the DisneyToon Studios animation _[Planes](/wiki/Planes_\(film\) "Planes \(film\)")_ (2013) playing Harland the pushback vehicle
  * Made commercials for Ontario's [The Beer Store](/wiki/The_Beer_Store "The Beer Store") with his Cheers partner, George Wendt
  * Appeared in _[Drop Dead Diva](/wiki/Drop_Dead_Diva "Drop Dead Diva")_ as Kim Kaswell's estranged father

## Other
work[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=7&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Other work")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/JohnRatzenberger08RIIFF.jpg/220px-
JohnRatzenberger08RIIFF.jpg)](/wiki/File:JohnRatzenberger08RIIFF.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:JohnRatzenberger08RIIFF.jpg "Enlarge")

Ratzenberger at the 2008 [Rhode Island International Film
Festival](/wiki/Rhode_Island_International_Film_Festival "Rhode Island
International Film Festival")

Ratzenberger developed a packaging-alternatives product made from
biodegradable and non-toxic recycled paper as a safe alternative to
[styrofoam](/wiki/Styrofoam "Styrofoam") "peanuts" and plastic bubble wrap.
This product was manufactured by his company Eco-Pak Industries, which he
later sold.[21]

Ratzenberger co-authored _We 've Got it Made in America: A Common Man's Salute
to an Uncommon Country_ ([ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number
"International Standard Book Number")
[1-931722-84-6](/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-931722-84-6
"Special:BookSources/1-931722-84-6")), published in 2006.

He also co-founded the Nuts, Bolts and Thingamajigs Foundation,[22] dedicated
to raising awareness among young people of skilled trades and engineering
disciplines.[23]

In 2010, Ratzenberger became affiliated with and now represents the Center for
America (formerly the Foundation for Fair Civil Justice) to further develop
his work and increase awareness about the skilled worker shortage facing the
United States and the changes needed to positively impact and increase the
number of skilled workers.[24] He joined as a Board Member in 2010.[24] CFA is
a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization whose mission is to "educate, motivate, and
empower the American people to understand they have the greatest stake in
removing obstacles to a fair civil justice system, innovation,
entrepreneurism, and job creation."[25] CFA creates multi-media educational
programs, publications, and website features that reach millions of Americans
through radio, television, and the internet."[25]

In 2016, Ratzenberger launched thegiftbox.com,[26] an e-commerce website that
allows customers to subscribe to a variety of monthly boxes.

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=8&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Ratzenberger has two children, James John born in 1987, and Nina Kathrine born
in 1989, both from a 19-year marriage to Georgia Stiny that ended in divorce
in 2004.

After dating for nearly four years, Ratzenberger married Julie Blichfeldt
(then 46 years old) on November 6, 2012.[27] Both Ratzenberger and Blichfeldt
were described as "avid outdoors enthusiasts, philanthropists, and
activists".[27]

## Political
views[[edit](/w/index.php?title=John_Ratzenberger&action=edit&section=9&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Political views")]

Ratzenberger, a [Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\)
"Republican Party \(United States\)"), said he considered [running for the
U.S. Senate in Connecticut in
2012](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Connecticut,_2012 "United States
Senate election in Connecticut, 2012").[28]

During the [2008 presidential
race](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008 "United States
presidential election, 2008"), Ratzenberger
[campaigned](/wiki/John_McCain_presidential_campaign,_2008 "John McCain
presidential campaign, 2008") for [John McCain](/wiki/John_McCain "John
McCain"), appearing with former _Cheers_ co-star [Kelsey
Grammer](/wiki/Kelsey_Grammer "Kelsey Grammer") at several Republican party
events.[29][30] He also has been outspoken in opposition of the [2010 health
care reform bill](/wiki/Health_Care_and_Education_Reconciliation_Act_of_2010
"Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010"), referring to it as
[socialism](/wiki/Socialism "Socialism").[31] He endorsed [Mitt
Romney](/wiki/Mitt_Romney "Mitt Romney") in
[2012](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2012 "United States
presidential election, 2012").[32] He appeared on _[Your World with Neil
Cavuto](/wiki/Your_World "Your World")_ to support [Donald
Trump's](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")
[candidacy](/wiki/Donald_Trump_presidential_campaign,_2016 "Donald Trump
presidential campaign, 2016") during the [2016 presidential
race](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016 "United States
presidential election, 2016"), shortly after Trump was declared the
presumptive Republican nominee.[33]

On January 17, 2010, he appeared and endorsed [Scott
Brown](/wiki/Scott_Brown_\(politician\) "Scott Brown \(politician\)") for the
United States Senate at [Mechanics
Hall](/wiki/Mechanics_Hall_\(Worcester,_Massachusetts\) "Mechanics Hall
\(Worcester, Massachusetts\)") in [Worcester,
Massachusetts](/wiki/Worcester,_Massachusetts "Worcester, Massachusetts").

Ratzenberger campaigned for Republican [Josh Mandel](/wiki/Josh_Mandel "Josh
Mandel") of Ohio for the State Treasurer position during the 2010 election and
on January 10, 2011, served as master of ceremonies for Mandel's swearing into
office.

In response to the [2012 Aurora shooting](/wiki/2012_Aurora_shooting "2012
Aurora shooting"), he said "Hollywood has to, at some point, admit that what
they produce does affect the minds of people.... If you just want to shock
'em... society will pay the price for that at some point."[10]
